--- title: "Intro to Data Science" author: "Lab 4 -- Statistics" engine: knitr format: revealjs: slide-number: c scrollable: false code-overflow: wrap code-line-numbers: false code-copy: hover theme: [night, slides.scss] reference-location: document footer: "[Programming in R for Biologists](https://njlyon0.github.io/teach_r-for-biologists/)" --- ## A Guide to Your Process ::: {.cell} ::: ### [Scheduling]{.blue} ### [Learning Objectives]{.purple} ### [Practice]{.pink} ### [Supporting Information]{.orange} ### [Class Discussion]{.gold} ## [Today's Plan]{.blue} - Muddiest Point Review - Statistics Background - Stats Roadmap - Fundamental Statistical Tests ## [Today's Learning Objectives]{.purple} After today's session you will be able to: . . . - Recognize continuous versus categorical variables - Identify which statistical test is appropriate given X/Y variable types - Perform analytical tests using R ## [Muddiest Point Review]{.gold} - Recurring topics from most recent MPs: \ - Function Tutorial Assignment Questions \ . . . - What other topic(s) would you like to review? ## [Statistics Chat]{.gold} {.smaller} - What previous experience do you have with statistics? - Do not worry if the answer is "none"! - I just want to get a sense for where you're at \ . . . - What terms come to mind when you think about stats? \ . . . - Have you heard of (or read about) any specific tests? - If so, what were they? ## [Statistics & Scientific Method]{.orange} {.smaller} - Scientific Method: 1. Ask a question 2. Make a hypothesis (educated guess for answer to question) 3. Test hypothesis with experiment 4. Analyze data to test hypothesis 5. Report results \ . . . - "Statistics" is what we do with our data to test our hypotheses! - I.e., whether we find support for our hypothesis or not ## [Statistics Justification Example]{.orange} {.smaller} - Hypothesis: adding Nitrogen (N) to soil will make sunflowers grow taller \ . . . - Test: Grow many sunflowers either with or without adding a set amount of N to the soil \ . . . - Data: After set number of days, measure height of all sunflowers . . . ![](images/sunflower-hypothesis.png){.absolute top=450 left=750 width="40%" fig-alt="cartoon of a small sunflower emoji labeled 'regular soil' and a larger sunflower emoji labeled '+N soil'"} ## [Stats Example Continued]{.orange} {.smaller} - How do we decide whether adding N to the soil resulted in taller sunflowers? - What difference in height would be "enough" to say whether we were right? \ . . . - What if _some_ of the +N sunflowers are _shorter_ than some of the regular sunflowers? - Does this mean our hypothesis isn't supported? \ . . . - We need to use a statistical test to evaluate our hypothesis! ## [Statistics' Role in Science]{.orange} {.smaller} - Statistical tests let us know whether or not our hypothesis is supported - These tests include some assumptions but they are well-documented \ . . . - Scientists assess the appropriateness of the statistics in _the same way they do_ for experimental design \ . . . - [A perfect experiment with inappropriate statistics is not good science]{.purple} ## [Data Science & Statistics]{.orange} {.smaller} - Today is **_not_** a deep dive into the math behind statistics! - There are whole classes devoted to that \ . . . - Professional data scientists have to look at data and pick an appropriate test \ . . . - In this class we’ll: - 1. Look at some typical test types - 2. Cover what data types are the best fit for each test ## [Data Science & Statistics Analogy]{.orange} - Statisticians are like artists - Data scientists are like art historians \ . . . - Data scientists recognize art and can talk about it but we _may or may not_ be artists ourselves! ## [Temperature Check]{.purple} #### How are you Feeling?

## [Hypothesis Testing Philosophies]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Null Hypothesis Testing ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Multi-Model Inference ::: :::: ## [Hypothesis Testing Philosophies]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Null Hypothesis Testing 1. Make hypothesis & "null hypothesis" - H~A~: Something is happening - H~0~: Nothing is happening 2. Assess odds of obtaining results as extreme as observations _assuming H~0~ is correct_ \ - Measured by [P value]{.purple} - Ranges from 0 (0%) to 1 (100%) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Multi-Model Inference ::: :::: ## [Hypothesis Testing Philosophies]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Null Hypothesis Testing 1. Make hypothesis & "null hypothesis" - H~A~: Something is happening - H~0~: Nothing is happening 2. Assess odds of obtaining results as extreme as observations _assuming H~0~ is correct_ \ - Measured by [P value]{.purple} - Ranges from 0 (0%) to 1 (100%) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Multi-Model Inference 1. Define many possible explanations for observation - I.e., many competing hypotheses 2. Compare model strength - Stronger models are better fit for the data and thus are more likely to be true \ - More on this in [Lecture \#5]{.blue}! ::: :::: ## [Philosophies Continued]{.orange} {.smaller} - Null hypothesis testing & multi-model inference are both good science! - Just different framings of a hypothesis . . . ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Does temperature have _more of an effect_ than rainfall on newt growth? ::: :::{.column width="50%"} - Higher temperatures and more rainfall affect newt growth ::: :::: ## [Philosophies Continued]{.orange} {.smaller} - Null hypothesis testing & multi-model inference are both good science! - Just different framings of a hypothesis ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Does temperature have _more of an effect_ than rainfall on newt growth? \ - Multi-model inference - Want to know which variable explains the data better ::: :::{.column width="50%"} - Higher temperatures and more rainfall affect newt growth ::: :::: ## [Philosophies Continued]{.orange} {.smaller} - Null hypothesis testing & multi-model inference are both good science! - Just different framings of a hypothesis ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Does temperature have _more of an effect_ than rainfall on newt growth? \ - Multi-model inference - Want to know which variable explains the data better ::: :::{.column width="50%"} - Higher temperatures and more rainfall affect newt growth \ - Null hypothesis testing - Want to know whether higher values result in effect on newts relative to lower values ::: :::: ## [Null Hypothesis: P Values]{.orange} {.smaller} - P values < 0.05 are called [significant]{.purple} - Significant P values mean you 'reject the null hypothesis' - I.e., you find support for your hypothesis! \ . . . - 0.05 < p < 0.1 is 'marginally significant' - A.k.a. weak evidence of support for hypothesis \ . . . - In science writing, ["significant" **_always_** means P < 0.05]{.purple} - Use synonyms for non-P value contexts - E.g., dramatic, substantial, important, etc. ## [Hypothesis Testing Chat]{.gold} - What questions do you have about this? \ . . . - Ready to continue? - I promise that is the end of the "stats theory" portion! ## [Temperature Check]{.purple} #### How are you Feeling?

## [Variable Types]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### Continous ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Categorical ::: :::: ## [Variable Types]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### Continous - _Must_ be a number! \ - Okay if coercible to number - I.e., months can become 1-12 \ - Examples - Sunflower height - Flower nectar concentration - Feather density ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Categorical ::: :::: ## [Variable Types]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### Continous - _Must_ be a number! \ - Okay if coercible to number - I.e., months can become 1-12 \ - Examples - Sunflower height - Flower nectar concentration - Feather density ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Categorical - _Does not_ need to be a number - Can be letters or numbers \ \ \ \ - Examples - Rainfall of 0 mm, 10 mm, or 20 mm - "Site A", "Site B", etc. ::: :::: ## [Variable Types Visual]{.orange}

## [Variables & Hypothesis Testing]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Response Variables ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Explanatory Variables ::: :::: ## [Variables & Hypothesis Testing]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Response Variables - Data collected to test hypothesis \ - Variable responding to treatment/outside force - Can be categorical or continuous \ - Also known as: - Y variables - Dependent variables (_depend on_ explanatory variable) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Explanatory Variables ::: :::: ## [Variables & Hypothesis Testing]{.orange} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} #### Response Variables - Data collected to test hypothesis \ - Variable responding to treatment/outside force - Can be categorical or continuous \ - Also known as: - Y variables - Dependent variables (_depend on_ explanatory variable) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} #### Explanatory Variables - Treatment and/or measurement of world \ - Variable explaining response - Also can be categorical or continuous \ - Also known as: - X variables - Independent variables ::: :::: ## [Statistics Roadmap]{.orange} \ :::{.r-stack} ![](images/stats-roadmap-v0.png){.fragment .fade-out fig-alt="two by two table with explanatory variables as the rows and response variables as the columns. The first row and first column are both labeled 'categorical' and the other row/column is labeled 'continuous'"} ![](images/stats-roadmap-v1.png){.fragment .fade-in fig-alt="two by two table with explanatory variables as the rows and response variables as the columns. The first row and first column are both labeled 'categorical' and the other row/column is labeled 'continuous'. Categorical response with categorical explanatory is labeled 'chi square', both continuous is labeled 'regression'. Continuous response with categorical explanatory is labeled 'ANOVA' while the opposite corner of the table is labeled 'generalized linear model'"} ::: ## [Regression]{.orange} {.smaller} - X & Y are _both_ continuous \ - Hypothesis: The slope of the line between X & Y is not flat - H~0~: The slope of the line _is_ flat \ - Examples: - Butterfly toxicity (Y) increases with time (X) - Tree diameter (Y) increases with age (X) ## [Regression Visual]{.orange} ::: {.cell .panel-center} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Scatterplot of penguin bill depth against bill length](slides_4b_files/figure-revealjs/regression-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## [R Stats Syntax]{.orange} {.smaller} - All R statistical test functions use the same syntax - Thankfully! \ . . . - Syntax is as follows: ```{.r} # Test effect of otters on sea urchins stat_test(urchin_count ~ otter_count, data = kelp_forest_df) ``` \ . . . - Some tests require other arguments - But the above example is a template of the fundamental bits ## [Regression Syntax]{.orange} {.smaller} - The function for regressions is `lm` - Short for "linear model" \ . . . - Example syntax: ```{.r} # Run a regression my_model <- lm(response ~ explanatory, data = my_df) ``` ## [Practice: Regression]{.pink} {.smaller} ![](images/hex-penguins.png){.absolute top=0 left=1100 width="12%" fig-alt="hex logo for palmerpenguins R package"} - You are studying penguins and want to test the following hypotheses: - H~A~: As penguin bill length increases, bill depth decreases - H~0~: Bill length and bill depth have no relationship \ . . . - Use a [regression]{.purple} to test the hypothesis and assign it to an object - What is the class of that object? What is its structure? \ . . . - Run the `summary` function on that object to get a human readable summary table ## [Interpreting Summary Tables]{.orange} {.smaller} - You (maybe): "Okay, cute summary table but is our hypothesis supported or not?" \ \ \

## [Interpreting Summary Tables]{.orange} {.smaller} - You (maybe): "Okay, cute summary table but is our hypothesis supported or not?" \

## [Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)]{.orange} {.smaller} - X is categorical _but_ Y is continuous \ - Hypothesis: Groups of X have different average Y values - H~0~: All groups of X have the _same_ average Y values \ - ANOVA function is `aov` \ - Examples: - Different countries (X) have different numbers of rabbits (Y) - Grazing on pastures (X) reduces plant height (Y) ## [ANOVA Visual]{.orange} ::: {.cell .panel-center} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Bar plot of penguin flipper length against penguin species. Error bars are standard deviation](slides_4b_files/figure-revealjs/aov-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## [Practice: ANOVA]{.pink} {.smaller} ![](images/hex-penguins.png){.absolute top=0 left=1100 width="12%" fig-alt="hex logo for palmerpenguins R package"} - You are still studying penguins but have new hypotheses: - H~A~: Penguin species have _different_ flipper lengths - H~0~: Penguin species _do not_ have different flipper lengths \ . . . - Use an [ANOVA]{.purple} to test the hypothesis and assign it to an object - What is the class of that object? What is its structure? \ . . . - Use the `summary` function to see if your hypothesis was supported - What difference(s) do you see between this and the regression summary table? ## [Chi Squared Test]{.orange} {.smaller} - X & Y _both_ categorical \ - Hypothesis: Categories of X affect categories of Y - H~0~: Categories of X are not related to categories of Y \ - Used in medical contexts and Hardy Weinberg Equillibrium - You may have encountered this in BIO 102 . . . ![](images/chi-square-table.png){.absolute top=450 left=550 width="60%" fig-alt="two by two table of fake data indicating the number of patients who are cured or not when given either a treatment or a placebo"} ## [Temperature Check]{.purple} #### How are you Feeling?

## [Upcoming Due Dates]{.blue} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### Due before lecture #### (By midnight) - Homework \#4 - Read [Model selection in ecology and evolution](https://www.uvm.edu/~bmitchel/NR385/Johnson_Model_selection.pdf) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Due before lab #### (By midnight) - Muddiest Point \#5 - [Draft 1]{.blue} of Function Tutorials - Double check rubric to see that you’re not leaving any points on the table! ::: ::::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
